concept.title: Attestation
concept.shortdesc: An attestation is a claim on something which is signed by an attestor. TokenScript enables wallets to create and manage attestations. This is done by an Attestation Card.

conbody.p: This can be a marriage certificate, a university degree, a nation state ID, an email address, an Ethereum address or anything else.

Attestations are usually signed data objects. They are useful on the web: They prove identity or possession of something. An email address attestations helps a website to be sure that the user owns the email address without having to resort to sending email verification code. An attestation of a car insurance can be used as a proof when you login on a car sharing platform, an identity attestation can be used to register a bank account, and an attestation of being an accredited investor can be used to streamline user experience of a STO.

An attestation is usually signed by an attestor, like a processor of video identification or an email verification service. However, an attestation can be self signed, like having the keys for certain blockchain addresses. In this case the attestation links a dataObject to an address.
A standardized attestation format has an enormous potential to smoothly integrate identity and other claims into the web.
Attestation doesnâ€™t need blockchain and token, but it can do a lot for a token, while at the same time token makes attestations more powerful.

An attestation can be connected to an Ethereum entity like the holder of a key pair. This allows to create cheques - the transfer of coins from a smart contract to someone who can provide an attestation for an identifier like an email address. Also, attestations of anything can be required to use a smart contract. You could create an ICO smart contract which requires an attestation of being a verified investor, or you could create a car sharing smart contract requiring an attestation of insurance.
Any delivery vs payment operation can integrate any kind of attestation which might be required for the process.
TokenScript is tailored to use attestations in a wallet and to make them part of the interaction with a token.

Attestations are usually offchain. They often carry private information, like identity, birth date or mobile phone number. This kind of information should never be saved on a public blockchain. Offchain attestations are data objects signed by an attestor stored on a local device.

Attestations can be used to create a proof of attestations which can be part of a transaction. For example, if you have a cheque smart contract the receiver needs to create a transaction which includes a proof of the attestation of the required identifier, like a phone number.
An attestation is a dataObject. The dataObject can contain any information, including public and private information. It can be signed by an Ethereum entity and attested to a token.
Attestations are non-transferable, but transferability can be achieved by attesting to another attestation.
Attestations can be fully expressed by an URI for easy and cross-compatible usage.
The attestation format takes close inspiration from the X.509 certificate specification, RFC-5280, but makes several fields optional, adds a few new ones and changes some formats.
There is still much work to be done. For example, we need a format that can do partial attestation by using Merkle Tree, or even zero-knowledge proof of attestation.
